choices.D: The data path changes for 10 Gbps links only.
choices.B: The data path changes for 10 Mbps links only.
choices.C: The data path changes for all links
choices.A: The data path remains the same for all links.

discussion.content:
A is correct.

By default, the reference bandwidth is 100Mps

R5#sh ip pro
Routing Protocol is "ospf 10"
 Outgoing update filter list for all interfaces is not set
 Incoming update filter list for all interfaces is not set
 Router ID 5.5.5.5
 Number of areas in this router is 1. 1 normal 0 stub 0 nssa
 Maximum path: 4
 Routing for Networks:
 10.10.10.0 0.0.0.255 area 0
 Reference bandwidth unit is 100 mbps <======

questions.question_text: If you configure one router in your network with the auto-cost reference bandwidth 100 command, which effect on the data path is true?

questions.answer_description: The NAT configuration acts only on packets permitted by a referenced ACL. As a result, the ACL can permit packets destined for the Internet, performing NAT on those packets. The ACL also denies packets going to the Enterprise, meaning that the router does not apply NAT to those packets.

discussion.content: tunnel interface usually use private IP.
B. Just don't use ip nat outside on Tunnel0 interface.

questions.question_text: Router R1, a branch router, connects to the Internet using DSL. Some traffic flows through a GRE and IPsec tunnel, over the DSL connection, and into the core of an Enterprise network. The branch also allows local hosts to communicate directly with public sites in the Internet over this same DSL connection. Which of the following answers defines how the branch NAT config avoids performing NAT for the Enterprise directed traffic but does perform NAT for the Internet-directed traffic?

choices.D: By asking the ISP to perform NAT in the cloud
choices.B: By not enabling NAT on the GRE tunnel interface
choices.C: By configuring the NAT-referenced ACL to not permit the Enterprise traffic
choices.A: By not enabling NAT on the IPsec tunnel interface

questions.question_text: Which two addresses types are included in NAT?

choices.A: The router will determine the IPv4 destination address.
choices.B: The source IPv6 host can use DNS to determine the IPv6-to-IPv4 address mapping.
choices.C: The host is statically configured with the IPv6-to-IPv4 address mapping.
choices.D: ICMP can be used to determine the IPv6-to-IPv4 address mapping.

discussion.content:
I would say B is correct

Dynamic NAT-PT translation operation requires at least one static mapping for the IPv4 Domain Name System (DNS) server

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipaddr_nat/configuration/15-mt/nat-15-mt-book/ip6-natpt.html
Correct answer is B. Bastex's link ; Dynamic NAT-PT translation operation requires at least one static mapping for the IPv4 Domain Name System (DNS) server.

A
"One of the benefits of NAT-PT is that no changes are required to existing hosts if NAT-PT is configured, because all NAT-PT configurations are performed at the NAT-PT device."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipaddr_nat/configuration/15-mt/nat-15-mt-book/ip6-natpt.html
Hosts knows nothing about mapping.

C is the correct answer.

Prerequisites for Configuring the Cisco IOS DHCP Relay Agent
Before you configure the DHCP relay agent, you should understand the concepts documented in the "DHCP Overview" module.

The Cisco IOS DHCP server and relay agent are enabled by default. You can verify if they have been disabled by checking your configuration file. If they have been disabled, the no service dhcp command will appear in the configuration file. Use the service dhcp command to reenable the functionality if necessary.

https://www.cisco.com/en/US/docs/ios/12_4t/ip_addr/configuration/guide/htdhcpre.html#wp1096452

ip helper-address command is configured under the interface and the question states which commands needs to be entered in the global configuration mode so the answer is not correct.
ip forward-protocol specifies additional broadcast services that can be forwarded, however DHCP is one of the 8 protocols that are forwarded by default by the ip helper-address command ( the others are Time, TACACS, DNS, TFTP, NetBIOS). So ip forward-protocol is not correct either.
ip dhcp relay is to configure additional option for the relay.
I have configured ip helper address many times and it works out of the box by just configuring the ip helper-address command under a interface. The only way it won't work is if the service DHCP is turnned off for some reason which will disable both the DHCP server and relay agent functions on the router so in my opinion this answer makes most sense considering the question is worded
Correct answer A. Beacause first step; ip helper-address configuration.

D
"Enabling a helper address or UDP flooding on an interface causes the Cisco IOS software to forward particular broadcast packets. You can use the ip forward-protocol command to specify exactly which types of broadcast packets you would like to have forwarded."
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipapp/command/iap-cr-book/iap-i1.html#wp1776761080

questions.question_text:
A packet capture indicates that the router is not forwarding the DHCP packets that it receives on interface FastEthernet0/0.
Which command needs to be entered in global configuration mode to resolve this issue?
